config.text: Experience Builder Demos
Table of Contents﻿
Time Zones

We all have an idea of what timezones are. That’s how New York’s New Year’s Celebration is always three hours ahead of the celebration in California! Have you ever wondered how timezones looked on the map?
Timezones allow us to have time that is consistent to the amount of daylight at a given place. If the world did not have timezones, then in some places there would be no sun at noon!

How were timezone regions decided on? Each fifteen degrees of longitude moved toward the east corresponds to moving the clock an hour forward. In practice, however, the irregularity of the time zone borders is necessary politically and for the convenience of the local populace.

An important term to keep in mind: GMT. This is a term you might have heard before. It stands for Greenwhich Mean Time and it refers to the zero degree of longitude. This is the region Timbuktu, Mali is in. All other timezones are offsets of GMT’s current time. We use the format UTC+# to show this offset. In short, GMT is a timezone that uses the UTC time standard. In the GMT timezone, its time is UTC+0.

How do we visualize timezones? We can use a Timezones dataset and calculate what time it is currently in the world. The dataset would include the timezone region, as well as its UTC value from GMT. Below is a snapshot of the dataset. The "Zone" column indicates the zone's UTC number and the "Colormap" column indicates the color of the timezone on the map.

Question 1

Let us say our location is Timbuktu which is in the GMT timezone. If it is 10am in Timbuktu , what time is it in Japan? On the west coast of America? Let’s say you are given functions to find the timezone of the country, as well as the UTC number: findTimezone(country) and findUTC(timezone).

instructText: Save current Timbuktu time in variable
Find out what timezone the second city is
Find the UTC value of that country
Add the value to the stored time
config.codeText:
If it is 10am in Timbuktu, Mali, what time is it in Tokyo, Japan?.

timbuktu_time = 10:00am
japan_timezone = findTimezone(“Japan”)
UTC_num = findUTC(japan_timezone)
return timbuktu_tim + UTC_num

config.text:
Question 2

Now let us choose any city/timezone we want. How do we find the time of a second timezone? A cool trick to keep note of is if you are heading west, you are subtracting hours, and if you are heading east, you are adding hours.

Example

The time in Brasilia, Brazil is 8:00pm. What time is it in Oslo, Norway? Brasilia is UTC-3 and Oslo is UTC+2. Since Oslo is to the east of Brasilia (this is shorter than the path west), we will add hours to Brasilia’s time. What is the difference between -3 and 2? The answer is 5. So we add 5 hours to Brasilia’s time to get 1am in Oslo.

instructText: Save first city time in variable
Find the timezone of the first city
Find the timezone of the second city
Determine the direction the second country is relative to the first country (look at a map!)
Use the correct operation on the UTC numbers
config.codeText:
If it is 5pm in Los Angeles, USA, what time is it in Brisbane, Australia?.

LA_time = 5:00PM
LA_timezone = findTimezone(“Los Angeles”)
Brisbane_timezone = findTimezone(“Brisbane”)
UTC_LA = findUTC(LA_timezone )
UTC_Brisbane = findUTC(Brisbane_timezone )
return LA_time + (UTC_LA ? UTC_Brisbane)

config.text: Climate Change

Question 1

You are provided with a dataset that predicts the rise in world temperature by the year 2050. Let’s plot these changes on a map in order to visualize. Let’s try placing the data on the map! You are given a gradient of colors to place onto the map depending on the predicted temperature change by 2050. The column with the temperature information is called “teow_eco_pa2014.temp2050.” There are eight temperature colors on the gradient. Keep in mind the order of the color statements: we do not want to accidentally overwrite a color we already chose for an area!

Additional Thoughts

﻿With your group, in general what areas expect the least amount of temperature change? What about the most? What conclusion can your draw from this? Think back to your lessons on causes of climate change and what areas of the world are most affected by it.

instructText: Pick an area in the data set
Store the temperature increase into a variable
If temperature >= 3.6, use color 1
Else If temperature >= 3.2, use color 2
Else If temperature >= 2.7, use color 3
Else If temperature >= 2.3, use color 4
Repeat for all areas

config.text:
Question 2

Rising Temperatures induces many other issues that are ongoing in our world. One major issue is rising sea levels. As Ice in the north and south melt, the sea levels rise. Coastal cities lose inches every year to the waters. In this question, we will be mapping out the sea levels across the world. Additionally, Look back on the previous page and see if the rises in temperature correspond to the rising sea levels on this page.

instructText: Pick one data point from the dataset.
Check the expected sea level rise from the dataaset..
Use the value to determine circle size.
Draw the circle size location of the point.
Repeat for every point in the dataset.

config.text:
Context: Attention GIS specialist! The UN needs help visualizing data regarding world populations. You are provided with a data set called World_Population_Counts and it lists each country along with its population. You can take a look at the data in the table below. Let's try to help the UN visualize their data!


﻿Question 1: Please use the Population Counts dataset to add a circle on top of each country, where the radius of the circle increases with the population of the country. The higher the population, the bigger you should make the circle.  You are given 5 circle sizes to work with. We will call the smallest circle "Circle 1" and the largest circle "Circle 5". The others are between Circle 1 and Circle 5. The bounds for these categories are stored in a different dataset called Population Bounds, which you can reference with the population of a country. Rearrange the instructions below to complete this task.

instructText: Pick one country from the Population Counts dataset.
Check the population of the country using the Population Counts dataset.
Use the Population Bounds dataset to determine circle size.
Draw the circle size on the country.
Repeat for every country in the Population Counts dataset.

icon.data: <svg viewBox="0 0 16 16" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M15.29 6.208L8 1 .71 6.208a.5.5 0 10.58.813L2 6.515V15h12V6.514l.71.507a.5.5 0 00.58-.813zM13 5.8L8 2.229 3 5.8V14h3v-4h4v4h3V5.8zM9 14H7v-3h2v3z" fill="#000"></path></svg>

config.text: Question 2: Please use the Population Counts dataset (which you used above!) and a new Country_Size dataset (which you can explore below) to shade each country based off of its population density in square miles. The population density is equal to the number of people in a country divided by the size of the country – that gives you the average number of people in any one spot! Remember that each dataset is organized by country names. Please make any country with a population density below 47 people per square mile green, any country with population density between 48-966 people per square mile white, and any country with more than 967 people per square mile blue!

instructText: Pick any country
Save the population value as Population
Check the country size
Divide Population by the country size as Density
Color the country according to the given color scheme
Pick next country and repeat!
config.codeText:
for country in population_counts:
  population = population_counts[country]
  density = population / country_size[country]
  if density < 47:
   country.color(“green”)
  else if density < 966:
   country.color(“white”)
  else:
   country.color(“blue”)

icon.data: <svg viewBox="0 0 16 16" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M15.29 6.208L8 1 .71 6.208a.5.5 0 10.58.813L2 6.515V15h12V6.514l.71.507a.5.5 0 00.58-.813zM13 5.8L8 2.229 3 5.8V14h3v-4h4v4h3V5.8zM9 14H7v-3h2v3z" fill="#000"></path></svg>

config.text:
Background


How do you think you are able to access information on the Internet? Where does it live, and how does it show up on your screen? Let’s find out! We will first get some context by going through an example of video calling someone in another country! Then, we will map all of the different landing stations and internet cables!


What if you wanted to hop on a video call with someone living in another country, such as Ethiopia? How would they be able to communicate with you?


Let’s start up Zoom. If you look closely in the settings panel, you can see where you’re connected to the “Zoom Global Network.” In our case, our video is being channeled through a data center in San Jose, California.

Internet Cables

How does data move through space?

The data goes through these cables, across the entire Atlantic Ocean, to get to our friend in Ethiopia. Each cable has two landing stations, where it starts/ends.


Now that we have a better understanding of how information travels throughout the world, let’s take a closer look at these fancy underwater internet cables!

Question 1


You are given a dataset, landing_points, which contains all of the landing points for all of the cables in the world. Each point contains its own ID, its latitude and longitude, as well as the ID of the cable that surfaces there. Let’s start out by mapping all of the landing points. Choose the correct options from the pseudocode below.

point in landing_points:


x_coordinate = point.

y_coordinate = point.

map.plot(x_coordinate, y_coordinate)

Question 2


Now, let’s try to draw the actual cables! Remember, each landing point contains the ID of the cable that surfaces there. How can we use this information to approximate the cable paths?

icon.data: <svg viewBox="0 0 16 16" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M15.29 6.208L8 1 .71 6.208a.5.5 0 10.58.813L2 6.515V15h12V6.514l.71.507a.5.5 0 00.58-.813zM13 5.8L8 2.229 3 5.8V14h3v-4h4v4h3V5.8zM9 14H7v-3h2v3z" fill="#000"></path></svg>

config.text:
point_1 in landing_points:


    cable_1 = point_1.

landing_point_1 = point_1.

   

point_2 in landing_points:

       

cable_2 = point_2.

landing_point_2 = point_2.


cable_1 cable_2 \


﻿ landing_point_1 landing_point_2:

   

x_coordinate_1 = landing_point_1.longitude

y_coordinate_1 = landing_point_1.latitude

x_coordinate_2 = landing_point_2.longitude

y_coordinate_2 = landing_point_2.latitude


map.draw_line(x_coordinate_1, y_coordinate_1, x_coordinate_2, y_coordinate_2)

Park Deserts

Who has access to green space in Los Angeles?

Background

A “park desert” can be defined as any place that is more than half a mile away from a park. Let’s explore where park deserts are in Los Angeles, and whether there are any correlations between people living in park deserts and their socioeconomic status.

Question 1

To figure out where park deserts are, we will use a dataset of all of the parks in Los Angeles. Each park data record has the park’s name, latitude, and longitude. Let’s first figure out how to plot them:

instructText: Pick a park from the dataset
Find its latitude and longitude
Use the latitude and longitude to plot the park on the map
Repeat for another park
Stop when all parks have been plotted

config.text:
Question 2

Now, let’s try to figure out the areas that are not considered a park desert. We can do this by drawing a circle around each park point with a 0.5 mile radius.

park in parks_dataset:


x_coordinate = park.

y_coordinate = park.

radius_in_miles =


map.draw_circle(x_coordinate, y_coordinate,

radius_in_miles)

Question 3

Finally, let’s figure out how to identify the areas that are a park desert based on the buffered points we just created.

instructText: Pick a point in LA County
If it is within a buffered zone, it is not in a park desert
If it is not in a buffered zone, it is in a park desert
